chapter.title: Draft and Production Documents
chapter.para: You can create draft documents for review or production documents for internal or external distribution.

A document's type is identified by its watermark and status bar text, its location, whether search engine spiders and Google analytics are enabled for the document, and what type of commenting system is configured for the document.

listitem.para: The watermark and status bar text appears on the cover page of PDF output, and as vertical text on the left edge of PDF or HTML output.

Configure your content to use Google Analytics to observe which pages are being read, what links are being followed, what searches are leading readers to our content, and other information that might help you update content. See .
You can configure your document to use the Disqus or HashCode commenting tool:

HashCode. Collects comments on internal and external content. If you publish a document on docs-internal or docs-beta, the comments are viewable internally only. If you publish a document on docs.rackspace.com, the comments are viewable internally and externally. Comments are stored on a Rackspace server and are not integrated with Facebook and other social media tools.

Disqus. Collects comments on internal and external content. Comments are stored on a Disqus server and might be exposed to the outside world through integration social media sites like Facebook. Depending on your settings, if you make a comment on content with Disqus, that comment might be shared with your Facebook friends and Twitter followers even if you commented while inside the Rackspace VPN.

section.title: Create Drafts
section.para: Draft documents contain the DRAFT watermark and status bar. A draft document can also contain draft-only text that appears in the draft but is removed when you remove the status="draft" tag from the book or article element.

step.para: In the main XML file for your book or release notes, add the status="draft" attribute to the book or article element.
For example:<book xmlns="http://docbook.org/ns/docbook" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" version="5.0" xml:id="writers-guide" status="DRAFT">

To configure content to be visible in the draft document only, add the security="draft" attribute to the content. For example: <para security="draft">Documents for internal distribution contain internal content appropriate for Rackspace employees.</para>

section.title: Add Watermark and Status Bar

note.para: You can also add text to the watermark bar by adding a processing instruction as a child of the root element: <?rax status.bar.text="CONFIDENTIAL" ?>
If the text is long, use 1.3.0-SNAPSHOT or later to make it fit by controlling its size like this: <?rax status.bar.text.font.size="50px" status.bar.text="LIMITED AVAILABILITY" ?>
The default size of the text is about 71.3px; 50px might be the right size for "LIMITED AVAILABILITY".

section.title: Configure the Watermark and Status Bar
section.para: You can configure the watermark and status bar text through any of the following <status="DRAFT"> <?rax status.bar.text="RAX INTERNAL"?>
A watermark is a line of text that appears on the cover page of PDF output and that identifies the product and document version.
Watermarks do not appear in webhelp output, though status bars do.

section.para:
You can generate the following flavors of PDF or web help output for a DocBook document:
Version Status bar/watermark text Description
Reviewer REVIEWER In-progress document. Shows remarks and internal and external content.
Internal INTERNAL Internal-only. Strips out all reviewer content but leaves in content flagged as security="internal"
External None. Customer-facing.
Draft DRAFT Add status="draft" to the <book> or <article> element. When status="draft" the watermark contains the word DRAFT and elements that contain security="draft" are included. If you do not add status="draft" to the root element, then elements with security="draft" are omitted.

section.title: Filter Content
section.para:
By using <security>internal</security> in your pom.xml, you can produce internal-only and external versions of same document where the external version is a subset of the internal one. Filter Content
Tag Description
<para security="draft">...</para> Filters out the specified content UNLESS the root element of the document has status="draft", which causes the watermark bar to contain the word DRAFT automatically.
<para security="reviewer">...</para>
Filters out the specified content UNLESS you set <security>reviewer</security> in your pom.xml. If you do set security to reviewer, the following things also happen:
Elements with security="writeronly" are filtered out.
The watermark contains the word REVIEW. Note that elements flagged as reviewer appear with yellow highlighting.
<para security="internal">...</para>
Filters out the specified content UNLESS you set <security>internal</security> in your pom.xml. If you do set security to reviewer, the following things also happen:
Elements with security="external", security="reviewer", and security="writeronly" are filtered out. Elements flagged as security="external" are filtered so that you could, if you wanted, have mutually exclusive versions of the same content for external and internal audiences.
<remark> elements are filtered out.
The watermark contains the word INTERNAL. Note that any elements flagged as security="internal" appear blue in the output.
<para security="writeronly">...</para> These elements are always filtered out. You can use it for stuff you want to suppress for now without deleting.

section.title: Configure Search Engine Spiders to Ignore Content
section.para:
Sometimes, you must publish documents on docs.rackspace.com for private betas. Though these documents are not listed on the landing page, your product team sends links to the document directly to users. To prevent random people from finding the content in Internet searches, configure search engine spiders to ignore content. To configure search engine spiders to ignore content
Add the metaRobots tag to your pom.xml file:<metaRobots>1</metaRobots>
When you do this, the following tag is added to all web help HTML files:<meta name="robots" content="NOINDEX, NOFOLLOW"/> This tag tells search engine spiders to skip this content.

note.para: Remember to remove this parameter when you are ready to leave private beta.

section.title: Configure Google Analytics

note.para: If your document uses the 1.0.5-SNAPSHOT formatting plugin or later and its branding is set to rackspace, Google Analytics is enabled and the Google Analytics ID is set. If the doc tools team changes this default handling in the future, all projects would need to enable Google Analytics explicitly.

section.para:
Use the <googleAnalytics> tag to suppress or collect Google analytics. Valid values are:
0. Suppresses Google analytics. Use this setting for drafts and internal-only documents.
1. Collects Google analytics. Use this setting for customer-facing documents.
To suppress Google analytics
Add the following line to the configuration section in the pom.xml file: <enableGoogleAnalytics>0</enableGoogleAnalytics>
To collect Google analytics
Add the following lines to the configuration section in the pom.xml file: <enableGoogleAnalytics>1</enableGoogleAnalytics> <googleAnalyticsId>UA-23102455-4</googleAnalyticsId>
The UA-23102455-4 value identifies our Google Analytics account.
